xxl.relational
Class Join

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.relational.AbstractResultSet
        |
        +--xxl.relational.Join
Direct Known Subclasses:
NestedLoopsJoin
public abstract class Join
extends AbstractResultSet

This abstract class represents the logical operator "Join" (natural Join).

It provides the methods

  • ResultSetMetaData getMetaData()
  • int findColumn(String columnName)
because these methods are equal for all implementations of "Join".

Example:
An implementation of "Join" is a subclass of Join and should call the constructor of Join: 


	super(r1, r2);
The metadata are now created as follows:

Each column of r1 has the same column index in the output of the Join. The columns of r2 are checked whether they are "equal" to a column of r1. If that is the case the join is computed for these columns. If not the column is added to the output. This means, in order to compute a Join for two given ResultSets r1 and r2 the user has to ensure that the columns that have to be joined are "equal", i.e. have the same column-name. Corresponding columns must have the same type, otherwise an Exception is thrown.
Those columns of r2 that have a column name, that does not appear in r1, are sequentially added to the join result.

In addition, there are three useful methods for implementors: 


	int originalResultSet(int column)
returns for a given column index of the join result
  • 1 if the column belongs to r1
  • 2 if the column belongs to r2
  • 0 if the column is a merged(computed) column. 

	int originalColumnIndexFrom1(int column)
returns the column index of the column of r1 If the given column does not belong to r1, the behaviour of this method is undefined. 

	int originalColumnIndexFrom1(int column)
behaves exactly like above - except of r2 instead of r1. For implementors there are two useful attributes of Join:
  • int l1 is the number of columns of r1
  • int[] columnsForm2 is an array and its length is equal to the number of columns of the join result, and
    columnsFrom2[i] == k
    means, that column (i+1) of the join result belong to (possibly additionally) column k of r2.
    If column (i+1) belongs only to a column of r1, k is set to 0.
Now column i of the join result is a joined column if and only if
  1. i is less than or equal to l1
  2. columnsFrom2[i-1] is not 0
holds.
Then column i of the output was computed from column i of r1 and column columsFrom2[i-1] from r2.
